3. ln -s ~/.kube/config ~/.kube/config.yaml
4. code ~/.kube/config.yaml
5. < at this point i would expect vscode to open ~/.kube/config.yaml and read it as a YAML file because of the extension and the file contents; but instead it opens ~/.kube/config and for some reason decides the contents are "Properties" >

data.title: Emmet suggestions in jsx/tsx files get triggered for js/ts objects
data.body:
jsx and tsx files get emmet by default.

i.e they get the `Emmet: Expand Abbreviation` feature as well as the emmet suggestions feature by default.

The latter can be annoying when a js dev types in something like `this.someproperty`. The first suggestion would be emmet trying to expand it to `<this class="someproperty></this>`

Current workaround is to set `emmet.showExpandedAbbreviation` to `inMarkupAndStylesheetFilesOnly`

data.title: VSCode - Integrated Terminal not clearing multi-lines entry when pressing ESC key.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->
 Integrated Terminal PowerShell not clearing multi-lines entry when pressing ESC key.  Please see Mike Robbins video tweet: 
Mike F Robbins @mikefrobbins 
@daviwil When pressing escape in the #PowerShell integrated terminal within #VSCode, only the first line of a multi-line command is removed. https://twitter.com/mikefrobbins/status/897831328233775104/video/1

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10 Insider Build 16257
- PowerShell Extension: 1.4.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In the Integrated Terminal PowerShell, type a multi-line command:

```
Get-Childitem 'C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0-beta.5\modules' `
| Where-Object{$_.name -match 'Microsoft.'} `
| Select-Object Name;
```
2. Highlight, "Run Selection" and then up-arrow to see the multi-line code.

3. Finally, press the Esc Key to clear the lines -> result in only the first line.

Apparently, the multi-line code has been cleared but the terminal session still showing left over code. So, the pressing Esc key is not clearing the cursor line

![vscodeinsider_2017-08-16_11-11-17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/29370922-d5884586-8274-11e7-829d-0d80a4d65e53.jpg)

data.title: [Feature Request] Parent multi-root folders
data.body:
You should be able to tell a workspace to **auto-populate live with all the folders in one or more parent folders.** It would work like how a single-root window does now when you add a folder containing multiple repos, except with git integration for folders one level down from the parent.

Before I switched to Insider, that was how I used VS Code. I had my "GitHub" folder with all my repos open in one window in single root, and I did all git commands from the integrated terminal because git integration didn't support my setup.

### Use case
I wager that it's extremely common for students to have all their projects for a class or language organized in a single folder. Also, most IDEs let you configure a default project folder. With the current multi-root setup, they have to manually add a folder to the workspace every time they start work on a new assignment. This can get arduous if they are creating and deleting projects rapidly while testing.

### Scaling
What if people want git integration two levels down? Or three? Perhaps, instead, VS Code can simply do git integration at the first level where it encounters a valid .git folder. That is a much more scalable solution, but there may be caveats I'm unaware of. It will probably become much more feasible [once enough extensions have updated to support multi-root.](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/396#issuecomment-315402932)

The considerations in this feature request may become unavoidable for the optimal user experience in the future, when multi-root becomes mature enough to become the default.

data.title: Does this editor actually work for people?
data.body:
This is probably a bit of a rant, but I am having widespread systemic issues trying to use Code for real - as in for professional development.

Basic usability features simply don't work - or work until they stop working, at which point an F1 -> Reload Window is required.

For example, TypeScript intellisense.  It works, then stops working.  Reload required.  This probably the root cause for why the F12 key stops working. 

Occasionally, the build command simply stops working.  Ctrl-shift-B stops doing anything.  Great.

Even though I have one task defined in tasks.json and it's set to be the default build command, when I press it, I still get a dropdown asking me to choose tsc as being the build command.  Why?!

A simple TSC->Webpack (both in watch mode) configuration appears to be basically impossible with the tasks.json unless I start using commands, gulp, or some other wizardry that I don't have the time to learn.  It really feels like whoever designed tasks.json's schema has never used an IDE before.  Why can't I just run two commands one after the other when I press ctrl-shift-B (and why isn't the default F5?)

And then of course there's the no multi-monitor support.  I know it's on the backlog, but it's a pretty big issue.

Finally - what's the deal with the 15+ Code.exe processes that are all using 100+mb of ram?  I feel like this increases every time "Reload window" is used, which is often.  Maybe my extensions are to blame.  Of course without some of them (e.g., TFVC) I can't really do my job so that's not a consolation.

I'm still using it because VS2017's quality has spiraled so far downward that it's even less usable than Code is right now with all its bugs for front-end dev with modern frameworks.

This editor has potential but these issues are holding it back, big time.  Please spend some more effort on the basics before cramming in more useless features like a CSS color palette picker.

data.title: Go to File doesn't find my JS files
data.body:
**UPDATE:** this might be related to JavaScript files and my `files.exclude` settings, see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/32638#issuecomment-322768797.

I've got a folder open which has many sub-folders, many of them containing `gulpfile.js`. However, when I do Ctrl+P (Go to File), they are not listed.

In the screenshot, I've executed a search alongside Ctrl+P to demonstrate this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/101152/29364664-8d7abe5c-8294-11e7-9cb8-2e80386d136c.png)

VSCode version: 1.15.0
OS: Windows 10

data.title: Debug console: be able to disable automatic scrolling to end

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: - VSCode Version: Version 1.15.0 (1.15.0) - OS Version: Darwin ecvaawplun5.local 16.7.0 Darwin Kernel Version 16.7.0: Thu Jun 15 17:36:27 PDT 2017; root:xnu-3789.70.16~2/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Run a debug session that generates a lot of output. 2. The debug console will automatically scroll to the end. Reproduces without extensions: No This has been tested with https://github.com/rubyide/vscode-ruby, but I would guess the same happens with other languages as well. When the debug console receives lots of output (say 10s or 100s of lines), it automatically scrolls to the bottom. For me, this is annoying since the errors I am most interested in are most likely at the _beginning_ of the output. Means I have to scroll up manually every time. Could we make this an option? (Auto-scroll on/off)

data.title: Implement MainThreadTreeViews.dispose
data.body: This method should clean the workbench state in the case when the extension host process goes down.

data.title: Minimap should not capture clicks on areas it doesn't show anything
data.body:
Right now the minimap also captures click below the area where it actually does show something. All the space with the red "line" I added to this screenshot takes clicks although visually it looks to be part of the actual editor window:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/183673/29359343-8e2dbaae-827e-11e7-93a4-90a94cd3968b.png)

The only indication that I am hovering an invisible "area" is the added "slider" thing on the minimap at the top.

Especially in split view, where the editor window is very narrow, this often makes you click on the minimap and scroll to the bottom of the file, instead of selecting some text or positioning the cursor into the text as you intended to.

data.title: Settings Search-Exclude no longer works on Windows
data.body:
Hello, I would like to report a bug that occurred when I updated my Windows VSCode to the July 2017 update.

- VSCode Version: 1.15.0 (x86)
- OS Version: Windows 10
- Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a folder named testme
2. Create a file name hello.js with 'hello world' as content
3. Create a workspace settings and set it to:

``` json
{
    "search.exclude": {
        "**/testme": true
    }
}
```

4. Search for 'hello' 
5. The result `hello.js` is displayed even though it should not

Cheers

data.title: PHP 5.6 @return keyword in function documentation upsets the code highlighting
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0 (1.15.0)
- OS Version: Mac OSX 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add @return (boolean) keyword to a method documentation
2. @return boolean does not produce this error

It takes return (boolean) as valid code keywords and the rest of the code after that is highlighted like comments or text.

If @return is replaced with @retur or something not @return, the documentation highlight works just 
fine.

In my case the methods are static.

data.title: Open another window by shift clicking on icon in taskbar
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0, though this applies to all versions I've used so far.
- OS Version: Windows 10.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Since Windows 7, it's possible to click on an icon in the taskbar ('superbar') while holding down shift and it will open a second, third, nth window. It's a small accessibility feature so users won't have to right click the icon and then click the jumplist menuitem of opening another window.

Somehow, VS Code does not support this or actively prevents this. It does have a jumplist menuitem for new window, but shift-clicking the icon does not result in the expected behavior, it simply goes to one of the already opened windows.

It's a small thing, but I would really appreciate it if this could be fixed. Or is the current behavior chosen for a good reason I'm not aware of?

Thanks in advance.
